Differential diagnoses such as bacterial conjunctivitis or allergic conjunctivitis are less likely but still worth monitoring if symptoms worsen or do not improve in a week.  Regarding treatment, current guidelines support supportive care for viral conjunctivitis, as antiviral medications are generally not indicated unless herpes zoster or simplex is suspected, which isn't indicated here. Education on hygiene to prevent transmission is crucial. Follow-up is necessary if symptoms persist beyond 1-2 weeks, or if visual acuity declines or pain worsens.
